com.emildiego.messageLog
Class baseLog

java.lang.Object
  com.emildiego.messageLog.baseLog
Direct Known Subclasses:
androidOutput
abstract class baseLog
extends java.lang.Object

The baseLog is an abstract class used to build the foundation of all out logging classes.

Author:
Emil Diego

Constructor Detail

baseLog

protected baseLog()
The default constructor. Used to initialize our instance. We default m_iLogLevel to only capture error messages and set the tag to "messageLog".

baseLog

protected baseLog(java.lang.String sTag,
                  int iLogLevel)
Used to initialize our instance with the specified tag and log level.

Parameters:
sTag - The tag used to identify the source of the message.
iLogLevel - The level of messages we want to capture in the log.
Method Detail

getLogLevel

protected int getLogLevel()
Get the current level of the messages being logged.

Returns:
An integer corresponding to one of the values LOG_ALL, LOG_DEBUG, LOG_SQL, LOG_MESSAGE, LOG_ERROR

setLogLevel

protected void setLogLevel(int iLogLevel)
Set the current level of the messages being logged.

Parameters:
iLogLeve - The level of messages we want to capture; corresponding to one of the values LOG_ALL, LOG_DEBUG, LOG_SQL, LOG_MESSAGE, LOG_ERROR

getTag

protected java.lang.String getTag()
Get the default descriptive tag being used for this log

Returns:
A String that contains the value of the descriptive tag.

setTag

protected void setTag(java.lang.String sTag)
Set the default descriptive tag being used for this log

Parameters:
sTag - A String that contains the value of the descriptive tag.

checkLogLevel

protected boolean checkLogLevel(int iLogLevel)
Check the specified log level against the currently set level to see if we want to capture this message or not.

Returns:
True if the specified log level should be captured, false if it shouldn't.

logDebug

abstract void logDebug(java.lang.String sMessage)
An abstract class that sends a Debug message to the log.

Parameters:
sMessage - The message we want to send to the log.
